Using another bus call may be costly. Will try using the previous UserMethodSetting bus.
Done

This is a generic non-system specific commit so I'd leave out mention of meta-ibm. You can mention that system owners can override the default of 0 for PowerRestoreDelay via an override in their meta layer.
Ack
Hmm, gonna need some more background here. 1 or 2 seconds I'd get but 44 seconds too long??
Yeah I assume there's another process interfering (the system flushing caches). This is an occasional case so included it. Typically the reboot finishes in the specified amount of time.
Yeah, if this was simulation then it may just be the nature of that environment. I think manually starting the discover service once BMC hits ready and ensuring the delay is consistent is good.

Starting at a 5 second delay in increments of 5 going up to 30 it seems that any delay more than 15 seconds is causing some sort of a race condition with systemd-resolved. Any delay greater than 15 seconds has the possibility of the caches being flushed before the reboot occurs, which delays the reboot for ~30 seconds. Anything under 15 is consistent.
Please confirm on real hardware we always see exactly 30s (+/- 1s).
Done
Please use the lg2 capability here to log the actual delay from powerRestoreDelay
Ack

oh shoot, I just realized that this property is "The delay in microseconds before invoke power restore policy after". It's in microseconds so 30 seconds is actually 30,000,000 for a 30s delay. Easiest to probably just use the "std::chrono::microseconds" chrono in the sleep_for below. And change this variable name to something like powerRestoreDelayUsec so it's obvious it's in microseconds.  No need to fully re-test, just be sure a value of 30,000,000 works as expected in simulation with your code change.
I was wondering why a long was used for this property. Got it.
Done
LGTM
